name: 文學與藝術
goals: To provide students with an introductory history of western art and its literary reception
syllabus:
**\*\*\*\*Course taught entirely in English\*\*\*\***

**Aims and methods**

The purpose of this course is to provide students with an introductory history of western art and its literary reception. Each week we will be looking at a different cluster of visual artworks and discussing it with reference to (1) its own cultural context and (2) a short literary text written in response or as a complement to it.

The course will, in the main, follow the chronology of the visual artworks that we will be considering. This means we will move from renaissance to modern/contemporary periods of artistic production. The literary texts we will be looking at are mostly poems from the twentieth century. Students on this course will always be encouraged to try out their own interpretations of works of visual art and literary texts alike.

The themes that bind the course together: ekphrasis, ethical forms of looking, written and visualized forms of desire, polyvalence (i.e. multiple meanings), writing/painting violence, modernity and nostalgia.

**Typical lesson structure**     

Student presentations (see Grading)

Teacher’s lecture and class discussion of work of art

Close reading and discussion of poem written as response or complement to work of art

**Grading**

Presentation (20%). Each student will do one presentation, **which should last no longer than 4 mins**. The presentation will usually provide background material on the artist/artistic period covered in the session. The presentation must include at least three images.

Midterm and final (40% each). In each exam students will compare and contrast two or more poems from the course. These essays will explain the poems’ dealings with the world of visual art.

Plagiarism will not be tolerated: document every source you make use of in your work.

**Schedule (may be affected by Taiwanese holidays)**

1\. Introduction

2\. Pieter Brueghel, _Landscape with the Fall of Icarus_ (c. 1558); W.H. Auden, “In the Musée des Beaux Arts”

3-4 Anonymous Flemish artist, _Medusa’s Head_ (c. 1600); Percy Bysshe Shelley, “On the Medusa of Leonardo Da Vinci in the Florentine Gallery”

5-6. Pieter De Hooch, _The Courtyard of a House in Delft_ (1658-60); Derek Mahon, “Courtyards in Delft”

7-8 William Blake, “London” (1794)

9\. Midterm

10\. Jean-August Dominique Ingres, _Roger and Angelica_ (_Ruggiero Delivering Angelica_) (1839); Dante Gabriel Rossetti, various works

11\. Vincent Van Gogh, _Starry Night_ (1889); Anne Sexton, “The Starry Night”

12\. Edvard Munch, _Girls on a Bridge_ (1901); Derek Mahon, “Girls on the Bridge”

13\. Pablo Picasso, _Guernica_ (1937) and other works; R.S. Thomas, “Guernica”

14\. Various works of art; Frank O’Hara, “Having a Coke with You”

15\. Willy Ronis, various photographic works; David Constantine, “Nude”

16\. Final

17\. “Flexiweek”

18\. “Flexiweek”
